item.title: Carl Williams first to suspect his lawyer was an informer - The Age
item.description:
Carl Williams first to suspect his lawyer was an informer  The Age

Murdered underworld boss Carl Williams was one of the first to suspect he was being double-crossed by his own lawyer, whose role as police informer 3838 has ...

item.title: Confiscated Essendon home of gangland figure Roberta Williams for sale - Domain News
item.description:
Confiscated Essendon home of gangland figure Roberta Williams for sale  Domain News

The former home of gangland figure Roberta Williams will be sold, after her failed bid to keep the property from being confiscated by the government.

item.title: Gangland hard man's end in Carl Williams' 'torture room' - Sunshine Coast Daily
item.description:
Gangland hard man's end in Carl Williams' 'torture room'  Sunshine Coast Daily

Mark Mallia was sitting in a chair with his hands tied and a gag in his mouth when Carl Williams entered the "torture room''. It was a tin shed in the backyard of ...

item.title: Carl Williams 'warned to flee overseas by Lawyer X' - Daily Telegraph
item.description:
Carl Williams 'warned to flee overseas by Lawyer X'  Daily Telegraph

The former wife of Carl Williams has revealed Lawyer X warned him to flee overseas as he was about to face murder charges in 2004. The gangland lawyer ...

item.title: Everything you need to know about Lawyer X - The Advertiser
item.description:
Everything you need to know about Lawyer X  The Advertiser

Lawyer X was a police informer with the perfect cover - she was a defence lawyer acting for Melbourne’s most feared gangland figures. She’s the missing piece of the Melbourne gangland war puzzle and the tactics police used to try and bring an end to the bloodshed which played out on the city’s streets in the late 1990s and early 2000s. Over the last week the Herald Sun has revealed the story behind the scandal, which has triggered a Royal Commission. >> FOLLOW EVERY TWIST IN THE LAWYER X SAGA HERE << While playing the role of trusted legal counsel, the lawyer — who was given the codename In...

item.title: Lawyer X tale of twisted justice - The Australian
item.description:
Lawyer X tale of twisted justice  The Australian

To look at him, you’d never know he was a killer. A neat, bespectacled, soft-spoken man, he had none of the bogan bravado that coursed through Melbourne’s gangland. That’s what made him so scary. As defence lawyer Zarah Garde-Wilson tells Inquirer: “If he knocked on your door to say he was there to fix your Foxtel, you would let him in in a split second.” Don’t be fooled. Even within the bloodthirsty context of the gangland war, “Cable Guy” was a particularly nasty piece of work. He was involved in the executions of three people, all carried out in full view of children: Jason Moran and Pas...

item.title: Lawyer X: The man in the golden coffin - The Advertiser
item.description:
Lawyer X: The man in the golden coffin  The Advertiser

He wrote this proudly, again and again, from his Barwon prison cell after he got a computer in 2008. Jotting off letters to family, friends and women — hundreds of them, most signed off with a dirty joke — buoyed his mood, too. Read in their entirety, Williams’ words showed a dry wit and a regard for others. He cared what people thought and offered favours freely. LAWYER X PART 1: THE SCORPION’S STING LAWYER X PART 2: THE HODSON BETRAYAL LIFE & CRIMES PODCAST ON iTunes, WEB OR SPOTIFY If he sounded more human, as he pointed out, than public perceptions, he also sounded more vulnerable. For ...

item.title: Gangsters, cops and Lawyer X: the police informant scandal that has shocked Australia - The Guardian
item.description:
Gangsters, cops and Lawyer X: the police informant scandal that has shocked Australia  The Guardian

In 2005, eight years after the murder of the underworld figure Alphonse Gangitano kicked off a long and bloody gangland war on the streets of Melbourne, a prominent criminal barrister agreed to become a registered police informant in exchange for a promise that her identity would be kept secret. The woman – known variously as Lawyer X, EF, and informer 3838 – had represented some of the gangland war’s most infamous figures, including Carl Williams and Tony Mokbel. If EF exposes herself to risk by not entering the witness protection program, she will be bound by the consequences High court r...

item.title: Gangland getaway driver eyes freedom in wake of Informer 3838 scandal - ABC News
item.description:
Gangland getaway driver eyes freedom in wake of Informer 3838 scandal  ABC News

A man serving a 20-year jail term for his part in the killing of underworld figure Victor Peirce could be the first convicted murderer to make a bid for freedom in the wake of the Informer 3838 scandal. A jury found Faruk Orman drove the getaway car for Andrew Veniamin when he killed Victor Peirce in May 2002. Premier Daniel Andrews this week called a royal commission into Victoria Police's use of the criminal barrister — also known as Informer 3838 and Witness EF — as an informer against her own clients during Melbourne's bloody gangland war. Ruth Parker, the lawyer for Faruk Orman — who w...

item.title: Teen's neck fractured in Barwon prison bashing - ABC News
item.description:
Teen's neck fractured in Barwon prison bashing  ABC News

A 16-year-old boy who was being held in Barwon Prison near Geelong has suffered a fractured vertebrae after being bashed by fellow inmates on Monday. Key points: - 16-year-old held in Barwon Prison for stealing cars - Suffered fractured neck after being bashed by inmates - Mother says her son had also been punched in the face by guard - Lawyers had asked for boy to be removed for own safety The youth spent Monday night in hospital before being released on Tuesday afternoon. His mother, who along with her son cannot be identified, was horrified when her son's lawyer called on Tuesday afterno...

item.title: Killing of three white men in California city racially motivated: police - Reuters
item.description:
Killing of three white men in California city racially motivated: police  Reuters

By Alex Dobuzinskis (Reuters) - A black man accused of shooting three people to death in Fresno, California, wanted to kill as many white men as possible because he expected to be arrested for another shooting, police said on Wednesday, calling the incident a hate crime. Kori Ali Muhammad, 39, fatally shot the three white men in downtown Fresno on Tuesday after realizing he was wanted for the killing of a white security guard last week, Fresno Police Chief Jerry Dyer said. "Kori Muhammad is not a terrorist, but he is a racist, and he is filled with hate, and he set out this week to kill as ...

item.title: A Rocco road to deportation - The Australian
item.description:
A Rocco road to deportation  The Australian

Arico, 38, known as ‘Rocky’ to his friends and criminal associates, came to Australia with his parents as a young child. He married here and has children but he is a resident, not an Australian citizen. When his jail term ends, Arico will almost certainly be bundled off to Tullamarine Airport and put on a plane back to Italy, deported on character grounds. Late last year Arico was convicted of extortion, intentionally causing injury and trafficking methamphetamine and cocaine. Details of his conviction were suppressed by the courts while he faced firearms and further drug charges. Arico fir...

item.title: Carl Williams hitman jailed for murder of gangland figure - ABC News
item.description:
Carl Williams hitman jailed for murder of gangland figure  ABC News

Contract killer Stephen John Asling, who murdered Melbourne gangland figure Graham "The Munster" Kinniburgh on the orders of Carl Williams, has been sentenced life in prison with a minimum term of 27 years. Mr Kinniburgh, 62, was gunned down by Asling, 56, as he got out of his car in the driveway of his home in Kew, in Melbourne's east, 13 years ago. It was one of the last unsolved murders committed during the more-than-decade-long underground drug war in which more than 30 people were killed. Asling carried out the hit with Terrence Blewitt under drug kingpin Williams' instruction. Both of...

item.title: Gangster wrap for our turf - The Advertiser
item.description:
Gangster wrap for our turf  The Advertiser

Melbounre underworld identity Mick Gatto said he was excited about his first visit to the Oval to see two of his friends settle Australian boxing’s biggest feud. “I’m quite friendly with both of them (so) I’d love to see a draw but it’ll be interesting. It’s a going to be a good night,” Gatto, who now works as an industrial dispute mediator. “It’s a beautiful city, nice and quiet. I might look for a bit of property and move up here,” he said. “It’s great, nice and laid back.” Gatto, a former member of the so-called “Carlton Crew” and acquitted of the 2005 murder of hit-man Andrew “Benji” Ve...

item.title: California Man Who Killed Security Guard Kills 3 More Before Capture, Cops Say - The Huffington Post
item.description:
California Man Who Killed Security Guard Kills 3 More Before Capture, Cops Say  The Huffington Post

A California man accused of fatally shooting a security guard last Thursday was captured Tuesday after fatally shooting three others. He allegedly shouted “Allahu akbar” as he was being detained. Kori Ali Muhammad, 39, was arrested in Fresno Tuesday morning after a shooting spree left three people dead in less than a minute, Fresno Police Chief Jerry Dyer said during a press conference. The suspect did not put up any resistance when police found him, Dyer said, and has been charged with four counts of murder and two counts of attempted murder. Officers had been looking for Muhammad after he...

item.title: Carl Williams behind killing of Melbourne gangland figure Graham Kinniburgh, court told - ABC News
item.description:
Carl Williams behind killing of Melbourne gangland figure Graham Kinniburgh, court told  ABC News

Carl Williams organised for underworld figure Graham Kinniburgh to be killed 13 years ago after a failed bid to have gangland rival Lewis Moran murdered, a court has heard. Stephen Asling, 56, is on trial in the Victorian Supreme Court for the murder of the 62-year-old who was gunned down outside his home in Kew, in Melbourne's east, in December 2003. Prosecutor Andrew Tinney SC told the court Asling and his friend Terrence Blewitt, who had since died, carried out the hit under Williams' instruction. Mr Tinney said Williams had initially contracted them to murder Moran who he had a "powerfu...

item.title: Crime chameleon’s secret life - The Australian
item.description:
Crime chameleon’s secret life  The Australian

Yet at 12.07am on December 13, 2003, on the road outside a two-storey home in Melbourne’s affluent northeast, police found the elder statesman of Melbourne’s criminal underbelly lying in a pool of blood, his arms outstretched and his .45 automatic Colt pistol resting on his right wrist. He had fired one shot in self-­defence but it hadn’t been enough to save him from what police at the time described as an “execution-style” killing. Almost 15 years later, a 12-person jury in the Victorian Supreme Court named his killer as hitman Stephen Asling, following a month-long trial where the court h...

item.title: Williams ex declared bankrupt - The Australian
item.description:
Williams ex declared bankrupt  The Australian

A Federal Court registrar today ordered Ms Williams’ estate be sequestrated after receiving evidence about a debt totalling nearly $300,000 owed to the Australian Taxation Office.

Ms Williams failed to lodge any documents in her defence and did not appear at court today.

Her former husband was beaten to death inside Barwon Prison in 2010 while serving multiple life sentences for murder.

Registrar Daniel Caporale said the bankruptcy notice had been served personally on Ms Williams, and also ordered her to pay over $7000 in costs to the ATO.

Ms Williams has prev...

item.title: No need to prove who pulled trigger in Victoria's proposed drive-by shooting laws - ABC News
item.description:
No need to prove who pulled trigger in Victoria's proposed drive-by shooting laws  ABC News

New legislation to combat drive-by shootings will be introduced to the Victorian Parliament allowing police to charge all occupants of a vehicle involved in a shooting, rather than having to prove who pulled the trigger. Key points: - Under proposed laws, sentences will be increased for recklessly shooting at buildings or vehicles - Police will no longer have to prove intent to cause harm or injury - All occupants of car can be charged with criminal activity Under the proposed legislation, sentences will also be increased for recklessly shooting at a building or vehicle. Police will no long...

item.title: Prison enforcers at war behind bars - The Advertiser
item.description:
Prison enforcers at war behind bars  The Advertiser

Matthew Johnson and Gavin Preston — once firm allies and founders of the notorious Prisoners of War gang — are now bitter enemies. The men are kept in separate high-security units of Barwon Prison under the highest level of monitoring legally available to the state. Johnson’s influence on other prisoners who are part of the Prisoners of War potentially makes Preston a target within the system. But Preston is understood to have gained support from inmates unhappy with the direction of the POW. There has been speculation that an attack last week on gangland figure Tommy Ivanovic was payback f...

item.title: Fresno rampage leaves families without fathers - CNN
item.description:
Fresno rampage leaves families without fathers  CNN

One victim was a security guard trying to keep the peace. The other three victims did nothing to provoke the gunman -- aside from being white, police said. What the killer didn't know was the stories behind the lives he took. Here's what we know about the victims in the Fresno shooting rampage: Carl Williams, 25 Williams was a hard-working security guard who earned the rank of supervisor at Monument Security. Carl Williams, an unarmed security guard, was shot outside a Motel 6 on April 13. Fresno Police Department "He was a class act -- there was no other way to put it," his colleague Rober...

item.title: ‘Williams’ hatred drove plot’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘Williams’ hatred drove plot’  The Australian

In the first day of the Victorian Supreme Court trial of Stephen Asling, who is charged with shooting Mr Kinniburgh as he got out of the car in front of his inner-east Melbourne home in 2003, crown prosecutor Andrew Tinney told the jury a “joint criminal enterprise” was responsible for the murder. “The murder of Graham Kinniburgh was carried out with the involvement of a number of people,” Mr Tinney said in his opening address. “The prosecution case is that four men were involved in joint criminal enterprise to carry out that murder. All men were equally responsible as those who pulled the ...

item.title: Google did not defame man with photos of him linked to criminals, court finds - The Guardian
item.description:
Google did not defame man with photos of him linked to criminals, court finds  The Guardian

An appeals court has found in favour of Google after a man claimed the search engine had defamed him by publishing photos of him linked to hardened criminals of Melbourne’s underworld. Milorad Trkulja sued Google, arguing when search terms such as Melbourne criminal underworld photos and Melbourne underworld criminals were entered, images of him showed up. He argued the search results put him in the same league as convicted murderer Carl Williams, underworld killer Andrew “Benji” Veniamin and drug kingpin Tony Mokbel. Related: Google is publisher according to Australian court | David Banks ...

item.title: Mother who gave evidence against gangland-linked son 'living in fear' - ABC News
item.description:
Mother who gave evidence against gangland-linked son 'living in fear'  ABC News

A Melbourne woman believes she was shot in the stomach as payback for giving evidence against her son,Rodney Phillips, who was sent to jail for arson attacks on the homes of the family of notorious gangland figure Carl Williams. Leonie Stuart was targeted through her security door at her home at Glenroy, in Melbourne's north, in March. Photo: Ms Stuart's spleen was removed after the shooting. (ABC News) "I've walked down (the hall), and next minute all I could see was this red laser light," she said. "Then next all I heard was a big echo noise and I heard it again, and I'm holding [the spot...

item.title: Gangland widow Roberta Williams looks to contest Bill Shorten's seat - ABC News
item.description:
Gangland widow Roberta Williams looks to contest Bill Shorten's seat  ABC News

The widow of gangland killer Carl Williams wants to run against Opposition Leader Bill Shorten at the next federal election. Roberta Williams has been chosen as the Australian People's Party candidate for Mr Shorten's seat of Maribyrnong in Melbourne, but her status as an undischarged bankrupt could rule her out of the race. The Federal Court declared Ms Williams bankrupt over a $300,000 tax debt last year. She also spent six months in jail in 2004 for her involvement in a drug ring that supplied 8,000 ecstasy pills to undercover police. The People's Party was registered in March in a bid t...

item.title: Council role for former top cop - The Australian
item.description:
Council role for former top cop  The Australian

Mr Overland, a former chief commissioner for Victoria Police credited with bringing the gangland war to an end, became only the second top cop in the state’s history to quit his post after he lost the confidence of the then Liberal state government. He has spent the past five years in Hobart, rebuilding his career as secretary of the Tasmanian Department of Justice. Mr Overland informed staff by email yesterday that he had resigned his post. Shortly after his announcement, a statement was published on the City of Whittlesea website revealing he had been appointed as the city’s chief executi...

item.title: Victorian Government backs down on decision to move rioting teens to Barwon Prison - ABC News
item.description:
Victorian Government backs down on decision to move rioting teens to Barwon Prison  ABC News

The Victorian Government has backed down on its plan to transfer Indigenous teenagers involved in recent riots at a youth detention centre to a maximum-security prison. The settlement came on the eve of an urgent Supreme Court case brought by the Victorian Aboriginal Legal Service to stop teenage inmates being moved to Barwon Prison near Geelong. The Government had planned to transfer 40 juvenile offenders to a segregated wing of the prison while the Melbourne Youth Justice Centre was repaired following a riot earlier this month. Dozens of inmates smashed doors, windows and security cameras...

item.title: Contract killer’s life sentence - The Australian
item.description:
Contract killer’s life sentence  The Australian

The 56-year-old sat passively in the dock of the Victorian Supreme Court as the sentence was handed down by Justice Stephen Kaye this morning. Kinniburgh, a veteran gangster and well-known known associate of the powerful Moran clan, was the 21st victim of the gangland war and his murder remained unsolved for more than a decade. He was shot just after midnight on December 13, 2003, as he was getting out of his car in front of his red-brick suburban Kew home where his wife and adult son were sleeping. Police found him lying facedown in a large pool of blood, his arms outstretched, with his .4...

item.title: $1m reward for information on murder of 'forgotten gangster' - ABC News
item.description:
$1m reward for information on murder of 'forgotten gangster'  ABC News

Willie Thompson is the 'forgotten gangster' in Melbourne's gangland wars. He was gunned down on a street Malvern East 15 years ago, and now Victoria Police is offering a $1 million reward to find out who murdered him. Thompson had connections to a range of gangland figures including convicted murderer Carl Williams and Nick Radev, he was known to be involved in drug trafficking and had links to Western Australia. Photo: Williams was murdered in Barwon Prison in 2010. (ABC News) He was shot dead at his car on Waverley Road on June 21, 2003, after training at a martial arts gym. Thompson, 39,...
